laws.summary: Tennessee enforces non-compete agreements if reasonable. T.C.A. § 47-25-101 provides statutory framework. Non-compete must protect legitimate business interest (trade secrets, confidential information, customer relationships) and be reasonable in duration, geography, and scope. Courts apply reasonableness test; will modify overly broad provisions. Employer-friendly overall but with increasing worker protections movement.
laws.statute_citation: T.C.A. § 47-25-101 (Restrictive Covenants); T.C.A. § 47-25-701 (Certain Restrictive Covenants Void)
requirements: LEGITIMATE BUSINESS INTEREST required: Trade secrets, confidential business/professional information, substantial relationships with prospective/existing customers, substantial relationships of trust/confidence
TIME PERIOD: Must be reasonable; generally 1-3 years considered reasonable, but context-dependent
GEOGRAPHIC SCOPE: Must be limited to area where employer operated or customer relationships existed
SCOPE OF PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES: Cannot be broader than necessary to protect legitimate interest
CONSIDERATION: For existing employees, must provide additional consideration (salary increase, promotion, etc.)
WRITTEN AGREEMENT required
BLUE-PENCIL: Tennessee courts will modify overly broad provisions to reasonable scope
HEALTHCARE: Healthcare professionals subject to reasonableness standard; must show protectable relationships/trade secrets
NON-SOLICITATION: Similar enforceability standards as non-competes
VOIDABLE: Non-competes deemed void if no legitimate business interest or unreasonably restrictive
EMPLOYEE AT-WILL: No additional consideration needed for at-will employees at hire, but may need consideration if applied to existing at-will employees
laws.notes: Tennessee enforces non-competes with reasonableness standard. Employer-friendly with blue-pencil modification available. Growing political discussion about restrictions.

laws.summary: Tennessee does NOT have statewide salary history ban. Employers may inquire about compensation history. Federal equal pay principles apply (cannot use to justify discriminatory gaps). No local ordinances in major cities. No current state-level salary history restriction.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Equal Pay Act (29 U.S.C. § 206(d)); Tennessee law lacks specific ban
requirements: NO STATE SALARY HISTORY BAN in Tennessee
Employers may inquire about prior compensation
Employers may consider salary history in hiring
Federal Equal Pay Act: Cannot use salary history to justify discriminatory pay based on sex
Must document pay decisions
Retaliation prohibited for discussing wages
laws.effective_date: Federal law ongoing; Tennessee has no state ban
laws.notes: Tennessee currently permits salary history inquiries. Federal equal pay principles prevent use for discrimination.

laws.summary: Tennessee does NOT require pay transparency in job postings or employee communications at state level. No state-level pay range requirement. Federal contractors subject to OFCCP audit requirements. No local ordinances. Growing national trend but not yet adopted in Tennessee.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Equal Pay Act (29 U.S.C. § 206(d)); OFCCP regulations for federal contractors
requirements: NO STATE PAY TRANSPARENCY REQUIREMENT
Employers NOT required to disclose salary ranges in postings
Federal contractors: Subject to OFCCP pay equity audit requirements
Must maintain payroll records
Recommendations: Establish pay scales; document decisions
laws.effective_date: Federal contractor rules ongoing; Tennessee has no state requirement
laws.notes: Tennessee lacks state pay transparency requirement.

laws.summary: Tennessee follows federal FCRA requirements. No state-specific ban-the-box law. Employers may conduct background checks at any time subject to FCRA compliance (written consent, pre-adverse and final adverse action notices). Courts permit if job-related and non-discriminatory.
laws.statute_citation: Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. § 1681); Federal ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12101)
requirements: FCRA Federal: Written consent required before background check
FCRA: Pre-adverse and final adverse action notices required
FCRA: Third-party vendor must comply with FCRA
NO STATE BAN-THE-BOX LAW statewide
Employers may ask about criminal history on application
Sealed/expunged/arrest without conviction: Generally cannot consider
ADA CONSIDERATIONS: Cannot discriminate based on disability
Recommendations: Ensure FCRA-compliant vendor; document job-related business necessity
laws.effective_date: FCRA ongoing; Tennessee has no additional state law
laws.notes: Tennessee follows federal FCRA with no state-specific restrictions.

laws.summary: Tennessee does NOT mandate paid sick leave or paid family leave for private employers. Federal FMLA applies to employers with 50+ employees. No state-run paid leave program. Private employers free to set own policies.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (29 U.S.C. § 2601 et seq.); Tennessee law lacks mandate
requirements: NO STATE PAID SICK LEAVE MANDATE
NO STATE PAID FAMILY LEAVE MANDATE
NO STATE-RUN PAID LEAVE PROGRAM
FMLA (Federal): Applies to employers with 50+ employees; 12 weeks unpaid leave for FMLA reasons
FMLA: Must maintain health insurance; restore to same/equivalent position
JURY DUTY: Cannot penalize
VOTING: Cannot penalize
Recommendations: Establish voluntary paid leave (beneficial for recruitment)
laws.effective_date: Federal FMLA ongoing; Tennessee has no state mandate

laws.summary: Tennessee enforces arbitration agreements under Federal Arbitration Act (FAA). Courts apply federal standards with Tennessee law interpretation. Arbitration must be mutual agreement in writing. Class action waivers generally enforceable.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act (9 U.S.C. § 1 et seq.); T.C.A. § 29-5-101 et seq. (Uniform Arbitration Act)
requirements: Arbitration agreements enforceable under FAA
Must be in writing; clear mutual agreement
Cannot be unconscionable
Must be supported by consideration
Class action waivers generally enforceable if mutual
Cannot eliminate statutory rights; must preserve remedies
Costs: Employer generally bears arbitrator/forum fees if employee cannot afford
Federal FAA preemption: Tennessee applies FAA
laws.notes: Tennessee enforces arbitration under federal FAA standards.

laws.summary: Tennessee follows at-will employment doctrine. Either party can terminate for any reason without cause or notice (absent contract/policy). Exceptions: cannot terminate for illegal reason, cannot violate public policy, cannot breach contract, cannot breach good faith covenant.
laws.statute_citation: Tennessee Common Law; T.C.A. § 49-5-101 (Whistleblower Protection); Federal Laws
requirements: DEFAULT: At-will employment; either party can terminate without cause/notice

EXCEPTIONS - Cannot terminate for: Race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age 40+, disability, military service (federal), jury duty (federal), voting, workers' compensation claim, wage claim, whistleblowing, public policy violation
WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION (T.C.A. § 49-5-101): Employee cannot be discharged for reporting law violation or refusing unlawful act
IMPLIED CONTRACT: Handbook or conduct may create enforceable contract
GOOD FAITH COVENANT: Implied in all employment
PUBLIC POLICY EXCEPTION: Cannot terminate for public policy activity (e.g., whistleblowing)
FINAL PAY: Final wages must be paid timely
AT-WILL DISCLAIMER: Should be clear; ambiguous language may not override contract
laws.effective_date: Common law ongoing; statutory protections as noted
laws.notes: Tennessee at-will employment with exceptions for protected activities and public policy.

laws.summary: Tennessee allows drug testing under reasonable circumstances. No specific restrictions on pre-employment testing. Post-employment testing permitted with reasonable suspicion or random policy. Marijuana (recreational and medical) NOT legal in Tennessee; employers can prohibit and test. Employer-friendly on drug testing.
laws.statute_citation: Tennessee law lacks comprehensive drug testing statute; Federal Drug-Free Workplace Act (41 U.S.C. § 8101); Federal ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12101)
requirements: PRE-EMPLOYMENT TESTING: Permitted; no state restriction
POST-EMPLOYMENT TESTING: Permitted with reasonable suspicion or random testing if policy provides
MARIJUANA: NOT legal in Tennessee (neither recreational nor medical); employers can test and prohibit
TESTING REQUIREMENTS: Written policy recommended; notice to employees; certified lab (SAMHSA)
CONFIRMATION: Positive screening should be confirmed
FEDERAL CONTRACTORS: Subject to federal drug-free workplace requirements
DOT-REGULATED: DOT testing requirements apply
REASONABLE SUSPICION: Observable evidence of impairment; document before testing
PRESCRIBED MEDICATIONS: Cannot test positive for validly prescribed medication; ADA may limit action
Recommendations: Clear written policy; notice to applicants; certified labs; document reasonable suspicion
laws.effective_date: Ongoing; no significant state law changes
laws.notes: Tennessee very employer-friendly on drug testing. Marijuana not legal. Employers have broad discretion.

additional_notes.general_guidance: Tennessee is EMPLOYER-FRIENDLY regarding worker protections. Enforces non-competes with reasonableness standard, no salary history ban, no pay transparency requirement, no state-mandated paid leave, permissive on background checks and drug testing. At-will employment with exceptions. Marijuana not legal.
enforcement_agencies: Tennessee Department of Labor & Workforce Development
recent_developments: Growing political discussion about non-compete restrictions (following national trend)
No recent significant worker protection expansions
Federal OFCCP audit requirements apply to federal contractors
